cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Orient-Royal Mail Line.
div.p: REDUCED SUMMER FARES FROM MAY TO OCTOBER INCLUSIVE.
OUTWARD to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. “Oruba" will leave Suez about October 5
R.M.S "Ophir" will leave Suez about October 19.
HOMEWARD to NAPLES, MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY.
R.M.S. "Ortona" will leave Port Said October 23
R.M.S. “Oroya" will leave Port Said October 8
Passengers returning by the Line obtain one-third rebate off the above fares if leaving England before the end of October.

S.S. Woroestershire 7,160 tons, will leave Suez about January 2nd.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON.
S.S. Herefordshire 7,182 tons, will leave Port Said about December 23rd.
SPECIAL REDUCED FARES TO GOVERNMENT OFFICIALS
Fares from Port Said to Marseilles £12.0.0 ; London £17.0.0 ; Colombo £32.10.0 ; Rangood £37.10.0
Fitted with Refigerators, Electric Light, Electric Fans and all recent improvements.
Agents in Cairo: THOS. COOK & Son, Ltd. For all particulars apply to Suez & Port Said : Wm. STAPLEDON & Sons Port Said Port Tewfix (Suez).

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Greece-Turkey Mail Service. - Shortest, calmest, most beautiful sea passage to Europe.

Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for Piraeus (Athens), Smyrne, Mitylene, and Constantinople, in connection with Orient Express luxe train for Sofia, Belgrade, Budapest, Vienna, Paris, and London.

p.hi: Palestine-Syria Mail Service with Extension to Turkey.

div.p: Fast steamers leave Alexandria 4 p.m. every Saturday and Port Said, 5 p.m. every Sunday for Jaffa, (Jerusalem), Caiffa, (Nazareth), Beyrouth, (Damascus), Tripoli, Alexandrette, Mersina, Larnaca, continuing in alternate weeks to Rhodes, Chios, Smyrna, Mitylene, Dardanelles, Gallipoli, Constantinople.

KHARTOUM IN 3 DAYS. Express steamers leave Suez docks 5 p.m. every Wednesday for Port Sudan (and Suakin), in connection with Suden Government Railways Express. Luxe Service to Khartoum, arriving 8 p.m. Saturdays.
Steamers leave from Suez 5 p.m. every Monday evening for Jedda, calling one week at Tor, El Wedj, Yambo Jedda, Port Sudan, Suakim, Massowah, Hodeida, Aden.
For freight or passages apply the Co's Agencies Alexandria, Port Said, Suez, Cairo. or for passages only to THOS. COOK & SON, HAMBURG-AMERIKA Linie, REISE-BUREAU or other Tourist Agencies

div.head: Deutsche Levante-Linie.
div.p: Mail and Passenger Steamships. Regular Service fortnightly from HAMBURG; weekly from ANTWERP; every 4 weeks from BORDKAUX direct to ALEXANDRIA; homewards every 2 weeks from ALEXANDRIA for ROTTERDAM and HAMBURG. Goods forwarded at through rates from all German Railway Stations on direct Bills of Lading to ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO, SYRIA, etc. Special facilities for conveyance of cotton, etc. from ALEXANDRIA via ROTTERDAM and HAMBURG to German manufacturing towne and particulars apply to ADOLPHE STROSS, Alexandrian Agent The following are expected at Alexandria: Dec 22 S.S. "Hythnos" from Antwerp - Dec. 25 S.S. "Royal" from Hamburg - Dec. 26 S.S> "Pyrgos" from Hamburg - Jan. 5 S.S. "Tinos" from Hamburg

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Seti now on the berth, will sail on or about Monday, July 17, to be followed by S.S. Menes.
S.S Tabor for Havre via Malta to sail about Saturday l5th inst.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo. Particulars on application to
R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

div.head: SUDAN DEVELOPMENT & EXPLORATION COMPANY, LIMITED
div.p: KHARTOUM: CAIRO Office, Sharia Kasr-el-Nil.

TRANSPORT DEPARTMENT. Six days White Nile Tourist Trip dep. Khartoum Tuesdays. Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at all Cairo Tourist Agents. - Special Steamers for private charter. - Trips arranged and transport of goods undertaken to all places on White and Blue Niles within navigation limits.

Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que : Avances sur titres fixes et en compte courant, Avances sur marchandises et consignations, Emission de traités et chèques, Emission de lettres de Crédit, Paiements par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France èt de l’étranger, Garde de titres Recouvrement d’effets sur l’Egypte et l'étranger ; le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds en compte de depôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe au taux de 3 o/o pour 1 an et au-delà. 31-12-906

LE CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN fait toutes opérations de Banque, notamment: Escompte d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'etranger. Avance sur titres.—Garde de titres.—Depots de fonds a vue et à échéance fixe avec intérêts aux taux suivants: 2 1/2 0/0 pour dépôts de 6 mois, 3 0/0 pour dépôts d’un an, 3 1/2 0/0 pour dépôts au délà d’un an. — LE CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN reçoit des Marchandises en consignation pour la vente et fait des Avances sur Cotons, Grains et autres marchandises. — 28337-10-8-907

The IONIAN BANK LTD. transacts all ordinary banking business such as:

Advances on securities, merchandise, warrants, etc. Buying and selling of exchange on all principal centres abroad. Issue of drafts, letters of credits and telegraphic payments. Current accounts are opened and: deposits at sight and at fixed dates are received on the following terms: 3 0/0 for deposits at 6 months notice; 4 0/0 for deposits at 1 years notice.

div.head: BANQUE DU CAIRE, LIMITED,
div.p: CAIRO.

The Banque du Caire Ltd., undertakes all banking business such as : Advances on deeds and securites, discount, cheques delivered at very best rates of exchange on all the principal towns of the world, telegraphic transfers, purchase and sale of stock and shares in Egypt and abroad, letters of credit issued, safe custoday at a low charge, of titles, deeds and securities, current accounts opened. Receives money on deposit at sight at 3% per annum.

div.head: CHRISTMASTIDE
div.p: "Christmas comes but once a year, and when it comes it brings good cheer."

So runs the old couplet—and aa far as the first line is oonoeruetl it ifl almost universally correct. But it fails to take into aooount such an exceptional state ot things as that to be found in this country Here we have a large Greek element, and while the Anglican Pro testant Church and the Latin Cburcbea gener ally celebrate the birth of Christ on December 2ôth, the Greek and Eastern Cburcbea defer their celebration till the 7th of January—the period of the Epiphany. Consequently we get in Egypt two Christinas Days in the year, ea* h observed by a large number of commercial.

men . indeed, so large is the Greek community here that practioally busioeea is suspended in moat houses on the later as well as the earlier date What a boon would this be considered in the busy City of London — at least by the employés, for such a state of things would hardly commend itself to the beads of firms, so greatly would it interfere with business of all kinds in that world's centre.

It is interesting to study the early records of the obeervanoe of Christmas Day. In a previous Christmas article we showed that its origin was distinctly pagan and quite unoon uected with the birth of Jesus Christ Indeed many early writers hold that it was s special providenoe that appointed the birth of Christ to take place in the midst of pagan festivals. Menander gives a long account of them, and considers that a festival held on the shortest day-the winter solstice—presented the op¬portunity of a transition to the Christian point of view , Christ, the sun of the spiritual world, beiug compared with the sun ot the amtenal world. The comparison was carried still further, for as in the material world it is after dark ness has reached its highest point that the end of its domiuion is already near, and the light begins to acquire freeh powet, eo, too, in the spiritual world Christ, tbt spinteal eon, must appear to make an end of the kingdom of darkness But the date to be observed presented a difficulty, and while the Western Churches decided on the 25th December, the Eastern Cburcoes deferred it till the Epiphany. Heoce the difference of dates at the preeeot time. Christmas is a time when absent fneods claim a goodly share of our thooghta Coupled with these, no doubt, in the minds of many Englishmen resident in Egypt, is the regret that they cannot be in the old country “to put their leg* under the parental mahogany. ’ and enjoy the roast beef of Old England, or the plump Norfolk turkey These art things that are perhaps not obtainable in this oountry But we would say to our young friends, Cheer up ‘ Cold storage has been introduced, and if you cannot feaston a good sirloin of8ootch beef, you may get that excellent subetitute, a joint of the rich meat that comes from all paru, North, Central, and South, of the Amenoau c ontinent and which loses so little of its flavour in the freeting process, that it is often enjoy ed »» much as, and eveo preferred before,— when the source from which it comes is not known the borne fed beef. And the children - (b e»s them ), what of them at Christmas time! A glance at the shop windows fully assures us that they are not forgotten. It is worth while to pay a visit to the bazaars and large drapery establishments if only to note the plethora of dolls, mechanical toys, and noveltiea of all descriptions that are offered to the purchasers O' presents for the little ones. The Christmas tree, too, is quite an institution in Egypt do we wish to “ooe and all, both great and small," a very Merry Christmas and a Happy New Year. Now a days it is the oustom to filter the wi»h to that for a Happy Christmas, and tak ing into consideration the very many cases where the season from various causes cannot be a merry one, the old wish often seems a mock ery. W scan wish everybody happiness from the bottom of our hearts The “good cheer" of Christmas is too well established a thing for the old customs ever to be broken The fashions may change and the Yule Log disappear, but never will Chnat- maatide oease to be associated with family reunions and general feasting. Of late years a growing tendeucy bas manifested itself to make the testi val a time for a more general lo>*enmg of the puræ strings than formerly That Christmas-time is the only period of the year that mauy open their hearts and their purees for the benefit of the poor is a sad reflection, and reminds us of so many people who only put OD religion with their dunday clothe»* aud feel when they take them off that there is uo necessity to think about spiritual matters tor another six days. None the lees do we rejoice to see the movement extend year after year, and if the progress is slow we trust that it will be sure In the large cities of Cairo and Alexandria we have many desti¬tute wanderers who will be glad to reoeive some of the good things of the season, and uo doubt the Rudolph and other Homas will receive au increase of support that will enable them to give the poor who apply to them a good Christmas meal

div.head: A Happy Christmas to all our Readers
LOCAL AND GENERAL.
div.p: The Moore Case
Yesterday the libel actions brought by Mr Moore against various Cairo papers were fixed for a special hearing on the 6th February.
The Egyptian Institute
There will be a meeting of the Institute on the 3th inst. at 5pm when Mr. Fourtan will make some observations on the Schizaster genus.

div.head: RELIEF OF LUCKNOW
div.p: COMMEMORATIVE DINNER
(Gazette's Special Service)
London, Monday

The Indian mutiny commemoration dinner of veterans is being held at the Albert Hall to day. the anniversary of the relief of Lucknow. The decorations are magnificent and special trains are being run from all parts of England 6(A) dinners and 664 hampers have lieen des patched to the absent veterans. Lord Roberts will preside. The organisation of the dinner is due to the “Daily Telegraph".
London, Tuesday

The Indian mutiny dinner was a great success. The King’s message, expressing the ap preciation of the Empire for the conspicuous services rendered under trying circumstances and with gallantry and endurance which were the means, under Providence, of saving the Indian Empire from peril, was enthusiastically received
MEETING OF PARLIAMENT
(Gazette's Special Service)
London, Monday
Parliament will reassemble on the 29th of January.
THE KHEDIVE
The Khedive has ordered a six wheel automobile of 80-horse power for trips in the Marient district. The firm of Lorrain Dietrich will make it.
IMPORT OF SPECIE
The imports of specie to Egypt between December 13 and 21 amounted to L E 42,946. including 5.600 Maria Teresa dollars, and the exports of the country to LE. 2,041
LUXOR NOTES
(From Our Own Correspondent)
Luxor, 19th December

Great interest is felt by everyone here in the French journalists, who came over on the Heliopolis and arrived at the Winter Palace this morning, especially in Mr Maurice Barré «,f the Academie Française,Mr. George* Kaiser, Mr .lules Huret of tlie “Figaro , who is ac .. mpanied h\ Madame Huret. Mr. Pierre Ban din al o with Ins wife, Mr Joseph Galtier ot the “Temps’ and Mr. Paul Adorn. Also of the party are Mr Nenray, Mr H«*ste, Mr. Quaed \hig. Mr Folie, Mr and Mr* Pierre I*fitti. Mr (Wlln, Mr Lon Parsons, Mr. Paul de Iave'age, Mr Leon Dommartin, Mr Jules He Rorehgrave, Mr George Hague», Mr Maurice MuretandMr.de Vermville. Mr C Shorter of the “Sphere who was one of the English journalist» who crossed by the "Egyptian Ferry has also arrived with his wife.
The visit of the journalists to I p|*er Egypt is unavoidably very -hurt, s me are returning to Cairo by the train de luxe to night, others tomorrow and a few going on to Assouan

The “Egypt" continues to attract many visitors anxious to seethe most up to date of river -teamer-. nnd her passengers are frequently over at the Winter Pllnce. A large contingent of them came to the first dance of the season which took place the evening of the 17th inst., and the scene in the delightful hall of the monster hotel was a very gay one.

div.head: THE PERSIAN SITUATION
div.p: THE SHAH'S INTENTIONS
(Gazette's Special Service.)
London, Monday

The “Times correspondent at Teheran states that the Shah lias signed a declaration which has l«eu sent to assembly to mark the renewal of the fidelity of the Constitution. The Shah has accepted the oondiboo* of the Meglise, including the punishment of the ringleaders of the riots end the dissolution of the court clique. The Shall received thé British end Rusrtian representative» and gave as»u ranees that he did noteutertain any intention A abolishing the constitutional regime.

div.head: EGYPTIAN CONSTRUCTIONS
div.p: TERMS OF RESALES

In further reference to the extraordinary meeting of the Egyptian Construction* which was held ou Sat unlay, we art now fa position to publish further details of the terms of sale etc on which the various branche* of the company are to be liauded over to their original owners

The McClure and Dorliug branch having suffered severely through scarcity of capital, the amount of £17,600 charged as goodwill must in consoqueuce be considered as a dead loss The term» of withdrawal are as follow» — The company take* 2,500 shares paid as part of the purchase price for Mr Dorling’s Hbareof goodwill, Mr Dorling take» over the stock in respect of which, through depreciation of giKsiwill tbecompauy bears a loss of £8,800, the company keeps the book omets and lia- bilities of the branch and Mr Dorling relin- quishes all his rights to the directorship and other benefits of the contract of February 1906.

According to the director*, the Grant, Bondi and Chinn branch would, on an adequate capital, have shewn excellent result», but the oompany not having sufficient means at its disposal for working capital, or to meet it» engagements with the manager, they have arranged with the firm of Grant, Bondi and Chinn who repurchase their busiue*» as a going concern and will also return to the com pany the 10 000 «hare» paid for good will, forfeiting at the same time the bill for £6,679, part of the purchase price of the branch stock maturing ou the 1st April 1908 and paying to the company the sum of £9,100 in cash.

The retiring firm will also pay the amounts owing by their branch to the head uffioe, and other branches of the company, amounting to about £5,000, Mr. Bondi to remain as manag mg director, while his company forego their share in the profits mal* tor the Construction* hy this branch during the past year, which profits amount to £2,200 also agreeing to forego their claim in arbitration for £4,000 on shares.

With reference to the G Boyes branch, the company retain laud at Rod el Farag included in the original purchase price, receiving from Mr Roves the sura of £4,000, value of stock, furniture fixings etc, the company is keeping the existing assets and liabilities of the branch and loses £880or the sale.

The land at Rod el Farag was purchased with a view of erecting larger maun tact unng work* as well as general depot for stock etc in order to centralize the business and reduce the working expenses, but in view of the present state of finances they propose selling this land at the first favourable opportunity, at an estimated depreciation of £9,000 The loss on the building oontract at San Stefano amount* to £1895, due to tbe injudi cious technical supervision , the company adds that this loss brought about tbe retirement of the technical superviser» at the tenmnation of the work

An estimate of 10 has been allowed for on outstanding debts, as an allowance for tbe possible failures of various debtors to meet liabilities in view of tbe financial crisis. The sum of £11.897 under the bead of preliminary expenses has been written ofl, as it was felt that the gradual extention of this sum would reuder the payments of dividends impossible for years
The value of the company s stock as distinct from the branches is £1,695, this after allowing for dead loss on cement which suffered from climatic conditions.

div.head: DISCOVERIES IN EGYPT
div.p: Among a number ot occasional lectures that have lately been given at the Cambridge Union, may be mentioned one by Dr. Grenfell on the fragment of a Greek history lately discovered in Egypt. This narrative, unknown to n* More, was obviously a continuation of Thucy dides. Were the whole of it extant oui knew ledge of the early fourth century B.c. would take on a verv different form. Even the scanty relics are enough to anuul eight pages of Grote at a stroke and to blow much German Quellenkntik into this air Dr Grenfel in dines with Wilamowiti and others to assign the book to Theopompus hut from hisdeecrip tion it seems to contain but little of that edifving rhetonc and personal criticism which we have been taught to consider as “Echt Theopompisch” in later compilers

div.head: PARIS-HOUSE GENEVA.
div.p: Mm. Auberge is exhibiting her models at the Hotel Villa Victoria, Cairo.

div.head: A CAIRO DIVORCE CASE
div.p: LADY VIVIAN AND MR. CURPHEY

We published a special telegram from London on Wednesday last announcing that Lord Vivian had obtained a divorce from his wife owing to her having committed adultery with Mr Alfred Curphey, th* well known Anglo Egyptian financier The case came be fore Mr Justice Bergrade last Tuesday. The detail* are as follows :—

His lordship gTSLted a decree nisi to the Right Hoo George C'reapigny Brabaion, Baron Vivian, on the ground of the misoooduot of his wife, Barbara (Neely, Ltd y Vivian, with the oo reepoodent, Mr Alfred Curphey There was no defense.

Mr. Rayford said Lord and Lady Vivian were married at St Michael’*, Pimlioo, in August* 1603, and lived at North Audley street. The married life for a time was a happy one There were two children In 1906 the petitioner went to Canada, and on his return, in October, oc d (ÿlrred the first real trouble, because be found a (hat hi* wife had arranged to take part in some theatricals at the Royalty Theatre He object ed, and finally per*uaded her to give up the idea

The following winter they arranged to go to Cairo, and then on a shooting expedition Be fore going, however, the petitioner spoke to his wife about tbe co respondent, whose acqu aintonce *he had made in Cairo Lord Vivian had got to know something about the oo respondent, and felt he was not a desirable person for hi* wife to know. The petitioner mentioned the matter to Lady Vivian before departing for the shoot in the neighbourhood of Khartoum On his ret urn to Cairo Lord Vivian found that his wife had made the aeqas in tance of tbe co respondent and some of the latter’s friend*, to whom the petitioner strongly objected

Subsequently I^idy Vivian told her husband that she had arranged to go on a motor tour through France, but when he found that the co-respondent was to be one of the party he objected, and told the co respondent that Lady Vivian would not be one ot the party In the end there was no motor party, and the peti tioner and hi* wife retained home

The co-respondent and some of his friends shortly afterwards returned to England, and Lady Vivian was constantly going about to different places, and would have nothing to‘ do with her husband In tact (said counsel', from the time Lord Vivian returned from the shooting axpedition Iiady Vivian refused to live with him as hi* wife In Apnl last she left her husband s house, intimating that she would not return Lord Vivian had made every endeavour to get his wife to return *nd give up the co-respondent

On one occcasion Lord Vivian went and saw hi» wire at the Coburg Hotel, where she was staying, and promised to forgive her if she would return But she absolutely declined his offer, and left the hotel in a motor-car Sub- sequently, it was ascertained that she was constantly in the society of the oarespondent in the Isle of Man, and with whom she stayed at the Boston Hotel on the night of October 25 last.
Lord Vivian, in his evidence, corroborating counsel’s statement, said that after the shoot ing expedition near Khsrtcnm his wife refused to live with him an his wife
His Lordship: What was the reason? — She refused, saying she did not wish it.
His lordship inquired who the co respondent wn*, and counsel said he believed him to lie a man of considerable wealth, who lived in the Isle of Man, and spent a great deal of his time at Cairo
Other evidence was called, and a decree nisi, with cost», and the custody ot the children was granted

div.head: NOTES FROM SUEZ
div.p: ARRIVAL OF MAHMAL
(FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT
Suez, Monday.

A salute of 21 guns announced thi afternoon at 2 10 pm the arrival of the Mahmal special train at Suet, which attracted to the station thousands of natives, awaiting to see the disembarkment from the train Shortly after 3 30 p m the procession accompanied by the Governor of Suet, Bimbashi De Turris, chief of polio®, a military band, and detachments of infantry, artillery, cavalry and coast gnards, paraded through the principal streets of Snet, and presented a grand sight Toward* the evening the Mahmal was conveyed to the Suet Docks, and placed on board the Khédivial Moil liner “Minieh ”, which will sail for Jeddah to-morrow

div.head: "BELOW THE CATARACTS"
div.p: This is the title of an exquisitely illustrated hook on the Nile Valley hy Walter Tyndall which wculd be an excellent choice for Christmas or New Year's present Tbe sixty coloured plates are as artistic as any similar representation» of modern and ancient Egypt that we have ever seen, and the letter press affords interesting reading Tbe author was the gueet of Mr George B Aldenon oo “Noah Ark" at Aboukir aod be gives a pleasant ao count of bis «ojouro on that craft with his genial boat We are glad to note that tbe author promises another book dealing with Egypt above Thebe» We can heartily recv>m mend this work to all residents in Egypt, ai it give* life-like picture» of modern Cairo and tbe ruin* up the nver, and tbe general “g*t up’’ of tbe work is in tbe higbeet degree artistic M Mr William Heinemann is the publisher
